reviewText:
When I first got my PC in 2008 *The day I started playing video games* Left 4 Dead was probably the third game I had in my library, I remember playing this game all the time with my brother and dad. We were obsessed with this game back then, it was the best experience for us.  I love the characters, guns, zombies oh yeah and especially the gore.

Me, my dad and my brother loved to play zombie apocalypse games, this was probably our first favorite zombie game that we first started playing together as a team. I laughed when my dad thought the witch one of the special infected was like the most overpowered zombie in the game, when my dad was busy with work the day me and my brother started testing more maps out in the game we wanted to try see if the witch is invincible, turns out she died, its the day I first crowned her with an autoshotgun.

Best time of life, me, my brother and my dad played this game for like 3 years none-stop. It was a very addictive game for us it was so fun for us. A few weeks after me, my brother and my dad got use to the game, I started doing research, found some cheat codes thats when I started cheating by testing out some cheat codes thats when I showed my brother and my dad about the cheat codes then we started using cheats after we finished every single map which was like throughout 2008.

This game is very impressive, I miss the old times when I use to play with my brother and dad.

100/10 gg, sweetest memory I had in 2008 with my dad and brother. â™¥

reviewText:
One of my favourite games ever. You and three friends will battles against hordes of 'infected' or perhaps become the vanguard of those infected to wreak terror and death on survivors as the 'sepcial infected'. This game prioritizes team work over twitch skills and is a great game for people who like to play with a dedicated group of friends.

I have not played for a few years and when I left the game was more geared for hard core players when compared to it's successor, Left 4 Dead 2. From a cursory look this still seems to be true. A great game, but for beginners I might actually suggest playing Left 4 Dead 2 first, and then perhaps trying the first game once you are a little more skilled. Getting quad capped by people will 5000 hours in game might not be your best first expereince of the game :)



HOURS ON RECORD : I don't play this game on my public account. I have over 400 hours played in Left4Dead 1 and 1500+ in Left4Dead  2 on my private account.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead is a solid co-op first-person shooter that, while clearly showing its age, is worth the small price you can pick it up for on sale.

Preface:I remember when I first started playing this game. I was scared of everything. I moved very slowly, cautiously, and ran from place to place, looking for the safest and shortest path to the next saferoom. When I finally finished a campaign and got to watch the ending cutscene roll, it felt like a real achievement.

Then I tried joining my first multi-player campaign and discovered a whole new world. Having someone running along with me, giving me helpful advice, and us all generally looking after each other as a team was a great experience. This is a game where good team-based gameplay is rewarded, and where people who go rushing off alone commonly end up getting themselves killed. Left 4 Dead feels like it was built for cooperative gameplay, from the ground up. There's safety in numbers, and when you're the last one standing and trying to survive on your own, you'll really feel just how alone you are in a hostile world where pretty much everything is out to kill you.

The game can be played in both single and multi-player. Up to four players control one each of four survivors as they all attempt to move from one safe area to the next. Any survivors not being controlled by a human player will be automatically taken over by the survivor bot AI. As they move through the levels in the campaigns, the survivors will encounter various enemies, including hordes of common zombies and some rarer 'special' infected. These special infected come with unique abilities that make good teamplay essential, as their attacks can disorient and even render lone survivors helpless.

Level Design:Levels are premade and static, meaning they never change from game to game. After playing the same campaign enough times, you'll end up memorizing the most efficient routes through the levels. Item spawns are also preplaced, so if you find a bottle of pills behind a dumpster in a certain alleyway, then that's what you can expect to find in that location in all future games you play. There is some variation in the fact that items won't always spawn where they're available to be spawned, but that's it.

At certain points throughout the game, you'll encounter various events that trigger attacks from hordes of zombies, or even spawn 'boss' infected, which helps break the monotony of simply going from point A to point B. Otherwise, the meat of the campaign mode consists of moving from one location to the next while shooting zombies and finding items. There are six campaigns; most of them have a total of five maps. In each campaign, there is constant visible evidence of the decay of society and the collapse of civilization through wrecked buildings, vehicles, piles of dead bodies, and more.

Game Modes:Besides campaign, 'versus' and 'survival' game modes are also available. In versus mode, up to eight players can join a single game session. Versus mode is basically a campaign where there are two teams of human players - one team controls the survivors, and the other spawns as special infected. The survivor team must attempt to make it as far as they can before being killed, while the infected team attempts to stop them as quickly as possible. Once the survivors have been killed or make it to safety, the teams switch roles, and the map is played again. This rotation continues until the entire campaign has been completed, at which stage, points are tallied up to determine the winner.

In survival mode, the survivors are trapped in certain areas found throughout the campaigns, and must hold out as long as possible against relentless waves of enemies that get more difficult as the game progresses. Gold, silver, and bronze 'medals' are awarded for lasting ten, seven, and four minutes respectively.

Sound:Music in Left 4 Dead adds not only atmosphere, but is also dynamic in that it changes depending on the situation. Impending horde attacks are met with the sound of intense drumming, the presence of an attacking 'Tank' (boss infected) comes with its own 'epic' theme, unique 'terror' music plays while being strangled by a 'Smoker' special infected, and so on. Leaving the music in this game on can actually help the player maintain situational awareness.

Survivors also call out and comment on things they see throughout the game, and the voice acting is generally good. Players can make the character they're controlling say certain things with the press of a button for quick communication in case they can't or don't want to type messages or use a microphone.

AI:The survivor bot AI does an adequate job of keeping together and shooting enemies, but has a habit of running directly into the player's line of fire. I also noticed frequent pathfinding issues, causing bots to get stuck before 'warping' to the player's location. Sometimes, fellow survivor bots also take an inordinate amount of time to rescue other survivors from the clutches of special infected if there is even a minimal amount of zombies occupying their attention. Incapacitated survivor bots also have the uncanny ability to close doors, which is not something the player can do.

The infected AI is very accurate and effective, and often 'cheats'. Hunters are able to claw survivors while in mid leap and even after getting shoved away, and Boomers instantly hit survivors once they get within range, before even completing their swiping animation, There is also some kind of oddity with hitboxes involving rocks thrown by Tanks, which allows Tanks to hit survivors round the corners of buildings.

Pacing/Networking:Game sessions can be hosted on dedicated servers or locally via a player's computer. The game runs very well on a slow connection - on a connection that had a maximum transfer rate of 8.5kb/s, I've managed to maintain a ping between 50-70 on a dedicated server within the same country. Depending on how quickly players rush through a campaign, game sessions can last anywhere from 11 minutes on the shortest campaign, to up to roughly an hour for a standard one.

The Good:
+ Great multiplayer functionality (netcode, built-in voice comms)
+ Quick drop-in, drop-out ability
+ Maps have decent atmosphere and varied settings
+ Great mod and add-on support

The Bad:
- 'Cheating' infected AI
- Linear maps
- Weapon variety is somewhat lacking
- AI has slight pathfinding issues
- Survivor bot AI can be annoyingly incompetent

Conclusion:
Left 4 Dead is a game best played with good, human teammates. Survivor bots will suffice in the beginning, but as your skill increases, you'll quickly see just how deficient bots are. Linear maps limit replayability, but this may be offset by the fact that so much community-made content has been released and is readily available for download - www.gamemaps.com/l4d

What's the point of getting this game when Left 4 Dead 2 has everything the original has, and more? The gameplay in the original Left 4 Dead feels different compared to the sequel. In Left 4 Dead 2, there is more of a focus on rushing through hordes while under continuous attack. In Left 4 Dead, the focus is more on waiting the horde out while staying in a defensible location. The maps that were ported over to Left 4 Dead 2 from the original game have also been modified to reflect this.

If you've got no one to play with and are just looking for a server to join, at this stage, you may have difficulty finding games online, depending on where you live. The game's lifespan can be significantly extended if custom add-ons come into play, and the game can also be tweaked using various command-line startup options. I found a lot of entertainment and cheap humour in watching the bots play campaign and survival by themselves while I spectated.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead is a first-person shooter game, an apocalypse survival game from Valve. The game is a zombie apocalypse game where you play as one of four survivors trying to get themselves to safety. These survivors are Bill, Zoey, Francis and Louis. They're trying to get themselves to safety as their story began two weeks after the infection. They themselves are immune to this virus while thousands of people already become hungry undead.

The gameplay is almost similar to any Valve game, you can play up to 4 players with friends or people from the internet and play together. The zombies in this game are also unique, you won't just meet regular zombies, there are special infected that has many special abilities which can get you some troubles. Hunters for example, likes to leap and then pinned the survivors by surprise. The most fearsome infected could be the tank or the witch, they are the worst. Witch can take you down with only single attack despite her pity appearance. Weapons are quite good here, there are pump-action shotgun, dual pistols, submachine gun, assault rifle or hunting rifle. If you're overwhelmed, simply toss a pipe bomb and that thing will attract zombies from you and then blow them up.

Graphics of Left 4 Dead is quite decent and impressive. The Source Engine has again prove its worthiness. Explosion effects, gore and blood effects, the sounds and the environment are all impressive, including the amazing ragdoll effects which makes the environment more chaotic. And still, the game runs pretty stable and smooth.

Overall, Left 4 Dead is a good game to play with friends. I recommend this.

+ Cooperative play.
+ Good choice of weapons.
+ Good graphics, engine and physics.
+ Many variety of zombies.

- AI team still not very improved.
- Harder difficulty is too hard.

Rating 8/10

reviewText:
IntroLeft 4 Dead, a series I simply cannot get enough of.
Played this game to Death on the Xbox 360 before I made the switch to PC and added an additional 880 hours into the game.
This review is extremely late, but I felt like it's the least I could do for one of the games I've enjoyed most.
Please keep in mind that this review is based off the memories I have of this game and how it was when the game was still alive, there will be an additional botch of text at the bottom regarding the current status of the game.

The Game
Developed by Turtle Rock Studios and Valve itself, Left 4 Dead 1 was one of the first shooters to combine Cooperative gameplay with Survival First Person Shooter gameplay. No longer could you win" the game by only caring about yourself. You need your teammates and your teammates need you.

Pros
â— Unique Cooperative Gameplay in every Gamemode! (Campaign
recommended:
Survival)
â— The Lobby/Drop-in system works flawlessy allowing players to effortlessly finding a game.
â— Free DLC.
â— Make your own Maps!
â— Low PC Specs required.
â— Get to play as Special Infected! (Yeah.. those Zombies..!) in Versus mode.
â— Scoring System in Versus allows for both Teams to make an insane comeback!
â— Very Easy to setup your own Dedicated Server.

Cons
â— Players have to download Maps manually
hoursPlayed: they are unable to download from the Server they are joining.\nâ— No Workshop.\nâ— The Game is unpolished in regards to exploits and bugs
voteText: Valve has never responded to countless reports and complaints.\nâ— No Matchmaking

you're very likely to end up with very unbalanced teams when joining Versus games.
â— Ragequitting is not punished at all.

The Community
The Community for Left 4 Dead is very comparable to Left 4 Dead 2

it has died a long time ago.

Current Status of the Game

reviewText:
Finally time to write a more complete review (I will be editing this a few times) of l4d.

I got l4d in a no-steam version years ago, played on a 4 player italian server and loved the game directly, after a while i spend lots of time on an modded 8 player called |ELITE| this was back in the days version 1.0.1.4. when this server went down I started my own server and modding them.
nowadays -=HERO=-[www.l4d-hero.nl] (the community that got started) has 7 servers including 1x l4d2.

While l4d1 and 2 can be modded, yet I am talking about a vanilla game at this point.

Why do i like/love this game is that the details, the gameplay (smoothness, way things move, design, charathers) are just very good.. you see they spend time in it to make it a good game, not what valve did with CC and Sacrifice, that was just lazyness.
Yet people will tell you that l4d2 has the same maps as l4d1, in a way they do, yet they are not the same, they used a few versus maps instead of the original ones to make it different, yet not in a good way.
In a while you will be able to download the l4d2 maps in l4d1 which makes it just an even better game that it is so you do not need to buy l4d2 ;)

The game gets more interesting when modding begins, while l4d2 has more options and run on a better engine then l4d1 iin my eye's it doesn't make it a better game..
Modding l4d1 bring lots of fun while it is easy and not to complicated, to make the game even more interesting.

A friend discovered that there are hidden upgrades in l4d1 that only can be achieved through plugin(s) Survivor Upgrades


All in all, I say get l4d1 over l4d2, when it is in a discount buy both and try it out.

reviewText: This game is balanced so that teams pretty much *have to* work together to survive. Players who run ahead are typically targeted by the game, and the game is harder with few players (so it's important that you *AND* your teammates survive!). Therefore this game--in my many years of experience with it AND in comparison to my many years of Counter Strike experience--tends to have a friendlier and more team-oriented group of players to interact with. I appreciate the game dynamics in L4D very, very much.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead is evil. It's gaming experience is dark, viserally frightening and frequently so intense that it will have you looking over your shoulder just to confirm there isn't a zombie behind you.

That is why it is so incredibly awesome!

So, without any further delay here are my top 10 reasons for why you should definitely buy Left 4 Dead:

1. The survivor characters are well thought out and very relatable.
2. The game has excellent replayability, even in campaign mode.
3. The achievements are carefully crafted, challenging and completely addictive.
4. It does what a zombie game should do: scare the crap out of you.
5. Multi-player is encouraged, rewarding but not always necessary.
6. The varying difficulty levels actually make a difference (just look at my hours on expert)
7. You can play as special infected in multiplayer mode!
8. The level and campaign design is amazing.
9. It's one of the best zombie FPS games ever.
10. It's just so much bloody fun!

My only criticism is that sometimes the available weaponry options feel restricted and limited, but that just adds to the challenge.

You don't just play Left 4 Dead, you experience Left 4 Dead.

So experience it today!

reviewText:
I am happy to recommend this game, though I have to admit it's best to purchase the sequel instead. Why? Because currently it is priced around the same level and the sequel has all the campaigns from the previous game included! This means more than a dozen levels with continuous zombie shooting!

In any case, this, just like its sequel, is an excellent game. Although it was released more than 5 years ago I believe it aged well - the game still looks good thanks to the well-developed Source Engine. Years later Valve released many updated including DLCs that expand upon the campaigns - the latest, The Sacrifice, came out in 2010.

Left 4 Dead is a great game! It is a coop-based, action-oriented survival horror game. It is pure fun to get rid of the continuous hordes of zombies with friends game after game! A highly recommended game and not just for the fans of the genre!

reviewText:
A strange infection suddenly started at Pennsylvania which was causing mutation to the body cells and loss of higher brain functions. After two weeks of this green flue caused by the highly contagious pathogen four immune survivors Bill a Vietnam veteran, Zoey a college student, Louis an IT analyst and Francis an outlaw biker were making their way through the city of Fairfield. After avoiding all the infected finally survivors were rescued from the Mercy Hospital roof but unfortunately they found the pilot is an infected too. Zoey killed him and the chopper crashed in an industrial district outside the city. Fortunately they found a vehicle full of weapons and so they went to the riverside. While their way after crossing road blocks they arrived to the local church. When they encountered some lunatic infected in the church they realized that the city is overrun. Then they decided to rush to the nearby boathouse for rescue. From there they reached the city of Newburg on the other side of the river but they got that most part of the city is in flames. So, the large nearby greenhouse was their shelter. But then when a military C-130 Hercules passed overhead they tried to follow it by travelling through the cityâ€™s business district towards the Metro International Airport. After arrival they found that the military had bombed the airport while infected pilots crashed planes in an attempt to land. Finally they managed to escape by the C-130.

But it crashed again and survivors found themselves on the outskirts of Allegheny National Forest. From there they made their way to a functioning yet abandoned military outpost. From there they were rescued to Northeast Safe Zone Echo which is supposed to be the only uninfected area not yet overrun. Although they were immune but yet they are carriers of the infection, so they were temporarily hold by the military. But the four escaped via train and travelled south by Billâ€™s insistence. Bill had belief that they can get long term safety at islands of Florida Keys. They found a boat by raising an old rusty bridge powered by a very old generator at portside town Rayford. The machinery noise of the process alerted a horde of all types of infected. But then the generator gave out. Bill sacrificed himself to restart it so that the other three can reach at safety.

If you like up to this then surely you are going to like the game. If you have already played it then may be your liking may increase. Moreover you may feel oneness with the characters by role playing! :)

reviewText:
The zombie apocalypse is here and that's the entire story you need to know in this cooperative first-person shooter and all the story you're ever told. You play as 1 of 4 survivors (Zoey the college student, Bill the war veteran, Francis the biker, Louis the IT guy). The character doesn't seem to matter, it's just a different voice and skin. They will talk to alert you of things like health, weapons, reloading and where you should go next. Left 4 Dead is geared toward online multiplayer, but you can play solo through the game where your computer partners are competent enough, but need to be guided by you. Instead of online multiplayer where the other players seem to just run right through each level.

The controls are simple, point and click to shoot like any first person shooter, right mouse button is for melee for when foes swarm around you and they will. You have a long range weapon (shotguns, oozies, assault rifles and so on), a pistol (or 2) with limitless ammo, a medipack to restore your health or someone else's, pain pills that will temporarily give you a health boost and finally an explosive thrown weapon like a flaming cocktail or pipe bomb. You can jump or crouch for better weapon accuracy and that's it. The combat feels very limited because of this.

The big drawing point to the game is some sort of smart engine called the director that will generate random zombies to come at you, so no play through is the same twice. Such as a zombie that was at point A of your first play through might be a wall of zombies or no zombies, or a female zombie in your next play through. These zombies will race toward you after a few moments of shuffling their feet that might result in your terror, but an entire game of zombies running to you gets old very quickly. Zombies can climb up areas, go under truck trailers and the animations are good in general. Weapons and ammo scattered outside of safe rooms will not be in the same place twice.

The game is broken into campaigns and levels that you can access any one at any time. The campaigns are brief and really take you out of the action when you need to load a new campaign after completing one. The levels have good atmosphere, dark, spooky, but it gets old very quickly. Most every level feels the same with generic buildings, generic exteriors, generic trucks.

Between the levels are safe rooms. Leave a safe room and make it to the next safe room to cap off the level. Then at the end of the level, you see your score and how you did against the other players. Who killed the most zombies, who took the most damage. Stuff like that.

To be honest it's not that good. It feels very one dimensional. Within the first few levels, you've seen all the game has to offer. You will quickly see all of its small variety of enemies zombies run straight at you, witches that stay huddled until you put a light on them, stalkers pounce on you until you are saved, smokers use a tongue to strangle you until you are saved and explode smoke, exploders that vomit on you and tanks that can throw you and take a giant amount of punishment. You will really need to rely on others for survival. The computer players will be very willing to help you, but the players in multiplayer may not be as willing or can't when you've been left behind or gone ahead.

That's it. The game isn't very long and for a game that touts its random enemy generator, it doesn't make me want to replay the game again and again. Combat is simple, enemy variety is lacking, but the game plays very smooth. Essentially left for dead is about mowing down tons of zombies and if that's your thing, this is the game for you. If you need puzzles in your FPS or weapon depth, it's not for you.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead is a co-op, first-person shooter video game, with survival horror elements thrown into the mix. Just like Castle Crashers, this game is for that special friendship group, composed of four friends. With this game, you will find a bounty of endless fun, especially when setting the game's difficulty to an all-time high, as it really gives you that experience of being an endangered species, with the more stronger zombies wanting you dead, thus extinct. From my point of view, you can already tell I hold this game in high regard. Probably due to the fact it is developed by Valve.

The story takes place in an unamed location, within Pennsylvania. A highly contagious virus known as th ''Green Flu'' swarms the state, causing heavy mutation to human body cells and brain functions, resulting in the loss of humanity, meaning yes, the birth of zombies.

Two weeks after the infectious outbreak, four survivors, William ''Bill'' Overbeck, a bold, Vietnam veteran; Zoey, a sassy college student; Louis, an optimistic IT technician, and Francis, an aggressive outlaw biker, the four heroes of this game make their way through perilous cities, discovering along the way that the virus is causing more dangerous mutations. On a side note, the story of this game is split into campaigns, going in chronological order from top to bottom and progressively, the story is carried out on to the games sequel.

The player takes control of one of the four survivors; only if human players are not involved, thus the survivors are controlled by the CPU. The main objection of the game is to reach the safehouse after each level of the campaign.

Beware to watch out for the special infected. These types of zombies are the strongest of the common infected and if you get incapitated by one, you won't be able to shake them off, but unless one of your fellow survivors lends a helping hand and kills the attacking zombie. So, this just goes to show that teamwork in this game is the key of getting farther and staying progressively stable to continue playing.

Guns and other types of defense and weaponry, (in the shapes of molotovs and first-aid kits) are scattered among the map, usually on different occasions. This mainly happens after holding off an entire zombie horde, where they break through from left, right and centre. All of these weapons that you find are frequently random, but you can stick to the weapon you like the most. Just make sure to search for ammo at a seldom pace, especially if you're playing on a much higher difficulty. When outnumbered, just remember to always keep your health up, along with your teammates, as every chip of HP is precious into reaching the end of your goals.

This game is simply fantastic, but is usually overshadowed by its sequel, Left 4 Dead 2; possibly due to the inclusion of all campaigns found in this one and carried out in its said sequel. The one thing I personally prefer from this game is the feel of the slightly tighter controls it has when compared to Left 4 Dead 2. I would say this one is for the competitive players and the sequel is for the casual players. Considering you could just mess around, with the Shrek mod and all, and don't tell me you bloody haven't. It's a lot of fun and of course, the modding community adds to Left 4 Dead 2's advantage, much to this games' disadvantage.

In closing, I definitely recommend this game to all who are fans of survival horror video games and those itching to test their own determination and teamwork with one another. If you have have the sequel, I would still recommend getting this first game, just for its originality and or the fact you can add it to your godly Valve collection.

reviewText:
NOTE: Review based solely on campaign mode 4-player co-op. You can play with 1-4 real players, with the rest of the slots being filled up with adequate AI.

TL:DR; If you can find some decent people to play with co-op, the other elements of the game wonâ€™t matter.

L4D is a first person co-op shooter published by Valve. The cooperative nature of the game makes it somewhat tricky to review as one needs to differentiate between the game itself and the people youâ€™re cooperating with. A good game played with poor players tends to sour the game while a poor game with good players tends to elevate it.

The game was built on the source engine; the same engine Half-Life 2 uses. There were times playing L4D that it felt like you could have been playing Half-Life and I found that a little distracting.

The graphics themselves were on par with Half-Life 2; they werenâ€™t pushing any boundaries but nor were they terrible. If anything, the graphics felt a little dated, but were smooth and allowed for relatively quick load times. Itâ€™s a trade-off.
Youâ€™re given a limited array of items / weapons to use in the game. It basically boils down to which playstyle you prefer: Long range sniper, mid-range assault rifle/submachine gun or close up shotgun.  All these weapons use up a limited ammo supply with the option of pistols with unlimited ammo also exists (still needing to reload however).  Also available are support items such as Molotov cocktails, zombie luring pipe bombs, medkits and pain-suppressing pills. Some additional variety in items wouldnâ€™t have hurt, but it doesnâ€™t detract from your experience.  (This is addressed in L4D2)

On the topic of limited array of things; the enemy types also suffer somewhat from this. At the end of the day however, youâ€™re fighting zombies, so what do you expect? Theyâ€™re a relatively slow-moving, minor inconvenience, offering limited threatâ€¦until they swarm. A music cue heralds the arrival of a swarm, often followed by an amount of swearing by the players, as players steel themselves against a brief onslaught of fast moving, swarming zombies. This threat can be a little more troublesome.

Audio cues precede another kind of enemy; a special infected. These inflected also cause players to pay attention and cry an alert as they often throw a spanner in the works of an otherwise simple turkey shoot. Some of them can be easily dealt with or in one case avoided entirely while others can pose a significant threat, an equivalent to a boss in other game franchises.

Lastly, the story. Normally the story would be one of the first items Iâ€™d address, but in the case of L4D itâ€™s only a minor part of the game. If story is what youâ€™re chasing, you wonâ€™t sate your desires here. It exists, but mostly in an overarching chapter introduction, justifying the setting of the map. In most (all?) cases, it requires the players to get from point A to B, usually with a pre-set, player-triggered  swarm encounter somewhere in the middle and another at the end. The story does allow for some interesting, oft throwaway lines of dialogue by the characters however, that allow some entertainment.

While L4D may not be the best game in and of itself, but itâ€™s a good co-op. If you can get some friends together and battle your way though it co-op, you should get a lot of enjoyment from it.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead is a first-person shooter which is focused on cooperation and team play.
A handful of humans remain immune to the zombie virus. You play as one of a small group of them. There is Zoey, a young woman; Bill, the grizzled veteran; Louis, the middle-class office worker and Francis, the biker. Armed with weapons, these survivors must battle their way through the undead.
In each of the game scenarios, you must battle your way to a series of safe houses that lead to a rescue point. You can have up to four players in a game, controlling each of the characters, or the AI can fill in and control the bots.
Each scenario is presented like a movie. At the beginning there is a movie poster showing the cast. If you survive, the credits" display the statistics for the game
date: like who killed the most zombies
hoursPlayed: who delivered the most friendly fire
voteText: and so on. The final credit shows how many zombies were killed in the making of the film and also the film is dedicated to the memory of those survivors who did not make it to safety.\nThe zombie horde that you battle is based on the "fast" zombies. Besides of the zombies there are also special infected. There is the hunter
helpfulPercent: which can leap across large distances to pin a survivor to the ground. Then there is the smoker
votesHelpful: which has a frog-like tongue that can grab a survivor by the throat. The boomer is a corpulent zombie that vomits or explodes to spray survivors. Getting hit by the substance will not only temporarily blind survivors
votesTotal: but it drives the zombie horde into a feeding frenzy. Last but not least there is the tank
votesFunny: he is brick of a zombie that can take an enormous amount of damage and dish out a fair amount. And finally
commentsCount: there is the witch; she is an enormously powerful zombie that can take down a survivor with a single swipe.\nAll maps of Left 4 Dead are available now in the sequel
column16:
so it would be cheaper to buy only Left 4 Dead 2.
Still I would say that Left 4 Dead is an incredible and highly replayable multiplayer experience that is definitely worth checking out.

Sounds 9/10
Graphics 9/10
Gameplay 10/10
Atmosphere 10/10

reviewText:
This a a very fun game with friends which was released 6 years ago and it never gets old. Too bad Valve ported the original Left 4 Dead campaigns to the second game, but that shouldnt stop anyone from buying this game! If you want the real  experience, please do buy this game, there are  different types of game modes such as Campaign, Versus and Survival. It's an awesome team game which never gets boring and it is always a different experience every time you play it.

So if you're a fan of zombie apocalypse games, then this game is for you.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

reviewText: L4D is a very fun game, great to play online in the co-op mode where it's you and your mates playing through the game levels, it can be very hard but great fun all the time. The versus mode is great too where you get a chance to play as the zombies themselves, itâ€™s a lot harder to play as them though because you need to use tactics and play very carefully or you die easily. The game itself is a mostly online multiplayer game which encourages team work as you keep each other out of harms and rescuing them from certain death which is inflicted by the different types of enemy you face. You can play it offline too which is a nice touch but to really achieve the full experience it is best to access online.\nOverall it's a great game to play, but doesn't last long enough, you will get through the main campaign pretty quickly, so there will be a lot of repetition as you play the same levels over and over again. Thankfully there are custom campaigns to download and play, and modded servers can be used which can change the gameplay experience.\n

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by the hours I played this game
I actually played this game for more than 500+ hours (on another account)
Even 8 years later I still love playing this game,many people say that it's not worth buying because all of this game's campaigns are ported to left 4 dead 2 but I must say I played both games and loved both but the nostalgic feeling I get when I play this game is what left 4 dead 2 failed to deliver I still recommend buying this game anyway here is the review

Pros:
+Graphics are great for its time
+Physics are great
+Gameplay is great
+If you get bored there are variety of game modes
+If you want more maps there are a lot of maps online to choose from
+Mods to customize the game
+Level Editor to make your own maps

Cons:
-I don't remember if I encountered any ^_^

Overall Rating: 10/10

reviewText:
Hello,

This game is the first in the series of left 4 dead games, and has largely been overtaken by the release of left 4 dead 2. There is however still enough of a playerbase for you to jump on at any hour of the day and organize a full group (4 players).

Despite what you may have read, left 4 dead 2 is not exactly the same game" as left 4 dead
recommended: such as the assortment of enemies and overall gameplay.\n\nLeft4dead is much more pure and vanilla
hoursPlayed: it has 4 primary special infected instead of the 8 in left4dead2
voteText: no melee weapons and less map event triggers/sidequests.\n\nIt would be accurate to classify Left4dead2 as an updated version of this game
helpfulPercent: but with that you're losing the simplistic gameplay of the first
votesHelpful:
for a much more contrived chaotic version of itself.

As far as the gameplay goes:

- This is NOT entirely what I would consider a survival game
votesTotal: it is not team based Resident-Evil
votesFunny: it is an episodic action shooter.\n\n- It is a team based game
commentsCount: while it is possible to operate solo within a map
column16: you're more or less dependant upon those you play with
column17: whether its AI or PC's.\n\n- The graphics and sounds effects are good for when it was released
column18: no complaints there.\n\n- Level layouts are done pretty well
column19: there are always a few bonus areas to explore
column20: you will never find you're stuck wondering where to go or what to do
column21: but because of this the game feels largely linear... I suppose this was the intention of the creators as it is broken down into goal oriented episodes/chapters
column22: as a result this game can start to feel rather repetitive after playing through a particular map a few times.\n\n- The game is never boring
column23: it is constantly throwing enemies at you
column24: and you're constantly rushing to finish the current map
column25: there is very little "downtime" other than the starts and ends of each map.\n\n- There are also two different modes of play offered apart from the regular "movie" mode. Survival
column26: where you have to survive in a set location for as long as possible while the difficulty increases and Versus mode
column27: where one team takes control of the zombies as the other team works its way through the map.\n\n- There can be a few bugs in the game
column28: such as those regarding players falling off buildings and teammates attempting to rescue them
column29: but largely the game is not full of any bugs that directly affect gameplay.\n\n- Personally I feel both L4D & L4D2 should have more weapons
column30: but you never get bored with what you're given.\n\n- Regular zombies in this game are "runners" they're not the classical slow / shuffling Romero zombies
column31: headshots are not required to kill them. In fact these are not "zombies" at all
column33: so shooting anywhere can result in a kill.\n\n- The amount of zombies/infected is determined largely upon the players movement through the map
column34: there is no significant set amount of zombies within each map
column35: player progress results in map triggers that spawn hordes of infected that rush to the players location. So moving slow
column37: etc will be of no real benefit if you're trying to avoid detection.\n\n- It has a few additional items one would expect
column42: gas cans and propane tanks...all spread out rather liberally across any map
column44: although it does significantly change in expert mode.\n\n- The game offers various difficulty levels
column45: the difficulty level does not affect regular zombie health
column46: instead it changes the the DMG they inflict on a player when hit. Special infected on the other hand are given HP & DMG increases. With each increase in difficulty the available additional items
column47: weapons and ammo on a given map will decrease. If you're wanting to play this as a "survival" game
column48: setting the difficulty to "Expert mode" may offer the play experience you're seeking.\n\n- L4D & L4D2 also seem to have a large map making community
column49: so there will always be something new you can decide to download and play through.\n\n- This series is not ignored by the company Devs
column50: and they don't hesitate to fix problems or show community support.\n\nI would recommend buying L4D/L4D2 as a bundle
column51: if you're interested in playing. If you're seeking community numbers I would not advocate purchasing this game over L4D2
column52: as most L4D players have migrated there.\n\nIf you enjoy team based gameplay and blasting away zombies to the point of nausea
column53: then this is probably the game for you.\n\nThese are well made games that are supported by their company
column54: you will never feel as if you had wasted your money
column55: even if you don't particularily like the game.\n\nEnjoy :)"

reviewText: Left 4 Dead 1 is the first instalment of the series, and still one of the best zombie killing games around, gameplay is fast pace, kill zombies and move to the safe room. Many types of infected to block your way (tank, spitter, jocky, hunter, Boomer,Smoker Charger and the whitch. Few diffrent gameplay mode,  single player, co-op, and multiplayer, Versus Mode, Survival Mode. There is allso Matchmaking, stats, rankings to show off to your friends or check others to  see if they are good. Graphics are nice to look at and the music is creepy and scary at times, depends on what is attacking you and your party. Voices of the characters are funny at times, will keep you entertained while playing. And there are 70 achievment to get, in regular and versus gameplay. This is a must have for killing zombies.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead is still a classic I will never forget nor stop playing. I used to play this on my Xbox 360 and have ever since. I recently bagged this and Left 4 Dead 2 on a bundle deal for Â£5 ($7) on Steam.

It was great to finally get to play this game on my MAC. It works superbly and runs great... and with the Steam Edition you get FREE DLC as a pose to Xbox which you must pay for each bit of DLC.

General Gameplay
The general gameplay is great. It runs very smooth on my MAC and the campagins are brilliant (Full Specs at end of review). I'd have to say that the campagins on this game are better than Left 4 Dead 2's campagins, but that's just my opinion.

Community
The Community on Left 4 Dead is decent... everyone is friendly and you rarely come across stuck up people who's aim is to troll. Left 4 Dead isn't as active as Left 4 Dead 2 (800 Players v 15,000 Players) but there is still some servers active and enough people to play the game with (although single player works just fine).

Overview
In general this game meets everything that I look for in a game. It has great graphics and great gameplay. For a classic game it's deffinetly a great buy and I would reccomend this to anyone who had a notion of buying it. What I will say is I do think you should wait until this is on a deal. As I said I got this game and L4D 2 for Â£5 together instead of Â£22. Deals happen ocassionally on this game. But when you catch it on SALE I suggest buying it.


Rating:

1. Must Buy
2. Get on Sale
3. It's alright
4. Not worth it
5. Avoid

reviewText:
I play this game for an entirely different reason than I would play Left 4 Dead 2. Both games are meant to be cooperative, but after getting rather good at L4D1, I feel that it's somewhat broken in terms of your partners being indispensable.

In L4D2, you absolutely need to work together as a team in order to accomplish your goals. If there's inexperienced people on your team or if you end up playing with bots, the challenge becomes much more difficult. Some of the guns have been nerfed in order to reinforce the need for partners. Also, you can't melee forever, like you are able to do in the first game. Your character eventually fatigues and your character will start to melee more slowly after a while. The maps are designed to prevent the group from hunkering down in a corner and waiting out the horde. Instead, you are meant to run and gun, trying to lessen the amount of damage you will take, since you can't hide in a corner and melee, which would allow you to prevent taking any damage at all. The finales are much more varied and definitely require some teamwork. Without human players backing you up, the finales on some of the new maps would be near impossible.

In L4D1, on the other hand, the infected are pretty easy to dispel if you stay in huddled in a single squad. All you need your partners for is to give you a shove to save you from the occasional special infected. As long as you stay in a team, you can save each other from any hazard. The game is simplistic and pattern based. All you need to do is follow audio cues to know what to expect. Hear some piano keys playing? A Hunter is nearby. Hear a howl? A horde of zombies is coming. It's at that point that you just look for the nearest building corner and crouch. Then, you melee and shoot until the horde eventually dies. The game is extremely simplistic, once you've learned how to read its cues. The finales are also a very simple pattern of horde, Tank, horde, Tank, followed by the rescue, at which point you have a horde and a Tank at the same time.

It's for this reason that I play it, though. I enjoy playing it while talking to friends or use it as an opportunity to make friends. I can spend hours talking to people while killing zombies. For me, it's like a chatroom with a teambuilding exercise built into it. When I play L4D2, on the other hand, I spend so much time focusing on the task at hand, that I can't stop and chat. Not to mention that it's an entirely different gaming experience, which I have yet to acclimate to. In other words, I still suck at L4D2, so I can't easily chat and play at the same time. So, for how I use it, I definitely recommend L4D1.

reviewText: I remember my first contact with Left 4 Dead. Saw one of many (at that days) gameplays and walkthroughs on YouTube and after watching first 5 minutes I watched next video, and next, and nextâ€¦ After 2 hours I was sure: I'm definitely gonna buy this game. I haven't had good enough PC that time, but first thing I did after getting new computer was installing Steam andâ€¦ meh, buying L4D2, what I regret. 3 weeks later I bought L4D1 and I couldn't believe that game could be so much messed up after just 12 months. The only bug I encountered in L4D1 is that Zoey's animation gets stuck in weird position after loading shotgun (but it's fine when it was empty or only one shell was loaded), and only if playing by Zoey. In L4D2 the most, huh, â€žcriticalâ€ bug I got was having all Survivors invulnerable for a few minutes after I somehow managed to shove Jockey off my head (big shame I didn't record it then).\nBesides this, L4D2 feels like it's just not polished â€“ dumb Survivors animations, even more overpowered weapons, cartoonish feeling, annoying behaviour of Special Infectedâ€¦ L4D1 is free of this flaws â€“ and that's why it's my favourite. Heh, in L4D1 I have only my own weapons sound mod in constant use, while L4D2 has about 1 GB of mods throw on it and I still can't get as much fun from it I get from L4D1. Big shame Valve practically dumped it in favor of money they get out of L4D2.

reviewText:
I owned the Xbox 360 version of L4D first.  However, this version is the best!  Read to the end to find out why.

Night of The Living Dead meets 28 Days Later...  what more could you ask for?

Everything you've heard about Left 4 Dead is true.  It's a great game, and while there's enough action and excitement to enjoy the single player campaign, this is mostly about the instant and gratifying co-op multiplayer that you can get out of it.  Playing with friends is a blast, but playing with complete strangers can also be a barrel of laughs.  Yes your co-op partners can make the gameplay more difficult for you, but to this day there is no end to the amount players that are still playing this timeless classic of an Zombie / Action / First Person Shooter.

Some things to know:

* Left 4 Dead has a fun campaign which can be played alone but is most entertaining when it is played with others.
* The story is bare-bones, and each campaign ends with a rather short bookend, but each chapter is it's own action adventure.
* While the story might be light depth and content, the game is presented in a very B-Movie Hollywood schlock fashion that should appeal greatly to classic and modern Zombie movie fans, but also first person action fans as well.
* Every time you play Left 4 Dead things may play out entirely differently than last time, this is especially true and adds almost endless replay value when playing with numerous different people including randomly encountered gamers.
** Left 4 Dead is regularly modded by the player community and provides endless hours of entertainment including all new ways to play the game.  This is why the Console verison cannot really hold a candle compared to the Steam version of the game.

I could go on and on about the game, but I think that Left 4 Dead has been reviewed by enough people that it isn't necessary.  I just figured I'd give my two cents and perhaps encourage anyone who still hasn't had a chance to enjoy this excellent action zombie horror game.  Here's the most helpful tip I can give you:  If you're a Zombie movie fan but don't own Left 4 Dead on PC, or World War Z on Blue Ray or DVD, then buy L4D and forget all about World War Z (and go read the book instead, cuz the movie sucked!)

reviewText: Good game engine, often feeling like a multiplayerversion of Half-Life, but 3 times better. Broad support for modding and addons, and plenty of those to be found on the web. Good fluent shooter gameplay with some dynamic stuff i.e.: items and pick-ups placed randomly (still at pre-defined locations though). Few glitches and a good overall stability. The game content is  mostly gore not horror, nothing really scary in there just disgusting.\nSadly the gaming community is the worst of all i encountered in any multiplayer game. There are players to have a good game with that is roughly 20-30% of the average gamer population for this. The rest of them are egomanic loners who love to waste your gaming experience by either rushing, sabotaging, or even outright teamkilling you. The former are the most frequent type, making you wonder why they even bother playing this with others when they would be much better off playing the game single player. Often you will find they set up fake accounts to troll" those who simply wish to enjoy an imersive campaign and play with a good team. (Votekick usually wont work
date: so just let them rush and wait until they get incapped and killed by a special infected or tank
recommended: then they usually leave because you did not save their royal butt.)\nSo
hoursPlayed: if you get this either have 4 or more friends you will be playing it with or be prepared to play this singleplayer more frequently than multiplayer. On a bright side the entire game can be finished in singleplayer and AI is okay as well

reviewText:
This is going to be more of a comparison than a review... but I HIGHLY recommend this game to all FPS Lovers! especially to those that have only played Left 4 Dead 2.

If you can tell the difference between a game that *deserves* (subjective) an 8 out of 10 vs a 9, or 10 out of 10, you might understand where I'm coming from (once again, subjective).

What makes a game good? that could be a number of things. I believe that more features does NOT make a game better. Neither do flashy visuals. What do we remember a game for?
~A bit of my background: I play old school games more often than newer games, and prefer them much more becuase they were, more often than not, a 'complete' package when purchased, and more often than games today, had 'polish'. I'd underline polish if I could (maybe I can and I don't know how hahaha)...

This game is WAAAAAY better than Left 4 Dead 2 in my opinion (if only it had steamworks! p.q).
The difference between Left 4 Dead and Left 4 Dead 2 is that the former is of the Surival/Horror genre, built around a Co-op FPS. Left 4 Dead 2 is of the Survival(/Action? *kinda vague*) genre (lacking the Horror), built around a Co-op FPS. -The difference between the two games is night and day to me (literally and figuratively). Left 4 Dead 2 feels more like an action arcade game than a Survival/Horror game to me.
-Left 4 Dead (1) has a better atmosphere, the lighting throughout the game and the time of day immerses me much more than Left 4 Dead 2 does, often times I'll peek sides of a door, enter the dark room, and check my corners. Depending on how thorough I am, I might literally jump in shock because I backed into the one Common infected in the room and she got 10 free damage on me with one smack! The first Left 4 Dead has suspense to me, it leaves me wondering what's going to happen, how the Developer is going to do things, this feeling of unknown whilst still being somewhat familiar as I can think on my feet and know how best to handle a situation.
Left 4 Dead 2 has a similar familiarity, but it's more of an imminent wall of death is coming at this part..." familiarity with the tedious events involving turning off an alarm or loud noise. I get that it takes a degree of preperation and I dig that
date: it obviously takes teamwork... it just feels as though it occurs too often.\n\nLeft 4 Dead 2 just feels like a chore with just about everything that I do in it. I had to patch the game up (with custom content) to make it a more 'complete' game
recommended: but even with Steamworks and the vast amount of devs (thanks to you all for your content making it more like the first L4D!)
hoursPlayed: some things just can't be changed.\n\nDo I have a bias? I sure do... I'll admit it (don't we all?)
voteText: but that's because my idea of an 8/10 and a 9/10 or 10/10 is glaringly obvious. An 8/10 isn't a bad game by any means.\n9's and 10's have polish. I would say Halo CE had more polish than the other Halo's (Halo 2 had little time for polish as it was rushed
helpfulPercent: but was VASTLY more polished than the sloppy Halo 4 with object collisions and other etc.).\nI believe a big bullet point is that the first game in a series makes or breaks the (potential) continuation of the series.\n-After that
votesHelpful: a company doesn't have to try as hard to 'make a name' for the franchise if they can just ride off of the first game's successful momentum. It's the same case with Left 4 Dead 2. Sure it has the original Campaign and survivors

commentsCount: due to the game having fewer variables for game devs to consider regarding balance). *More Variables=Less Balance* "way she goes bud".\n-Left 4 Dead (1) has better sounds (music included that draws me and my friends in)

reviewText:
This review is from a single player perspective and if it were from a coop perspective my score would probably be higher.
This game is very fun to play:
- You get to kill a lot of zombies - always a benefit.
- There are  few unique zombies and 2 of them can be extremely powerful on higher difficulty.
- There are few different maps and the game doesn't feel repeating.
- Working on valve source engine.
- A very good combat system.
- A dark environment - fitting to a zombie game.

This game also get a con that can be annoying from a single player perspective - the bots AI is annoying for some time and they can get you killed and even make you restart the level.
In addition the game doesn't get a large variety of weapons and can be too dark sometimes (completely dark rooms with nothing in it, not even zombies).

Would recommend this game for both single and coop players but for the coop players you should buy this game with friends because that left 4 dead is dead on the online aspect.

My score: 8/10

reviewText: The original Left 4 Dead was the definitive zombie co-op experience, and it's certainly worth getting on sale if you're looking to go old school. However, Left 4 Dead 2 drastically improved on the formula with better graphics & animation, new weapons, and new game modes. Plus, all the maps from the original Left 4 Dead are included, including Crash Course & The Sacrifice! So just buy L4D2 - or, better yet, wait till they're both on sale in a package! Points for nolstagic value.

Release Date: November 17, 2008

-Left 4 Dead (1) has a better atmosphere, the lighting throughout the game and the time of day immerses me much more than Left 4 Dead 2 does, often times I'll peek sides of a door, enter the dark room, and check my corners. Depending on how thorough I am, I might literally jump in shock because I backed into the one Common infected in the room and she got 10 free damage on me with one smack! The first Left 4 Dead has suspense to me, it leaves me wondering what's going to happen, how the Developer is going to do things, this feeling of unknown whilst still being somewhat familiar as I can think on my feet and know how best to handle a situation.

reviewText:
I love Left 4 Dead. The atmosphere, the visuals, the pacing, the humor, the maps.

Valve reinvented co-operative gameplay with this title. Sure, there have been multiplayer games that let you mash bad guys as a group, but never done as thoroughly as L4D does it. Your team's survival depends on teamwork. And yet, it's never complicated. L4D rewards you for behaving exactly as you should behave if there really was a zombie apocalypse. Stay together as a group, watch each other's back. Share resources.

The Versus mode exemplifies these themes too, in that the infected team works best if the individuals cooperate and coordinate.

All of this adds up to an awesome beer & pretzels" alternative to your usual hardcore fare.

L4D2 one-ups L4D in many ways
date: but the atmosphere of the original is much darker. When Valve adapts all L4D maps for L4D2
recommended: there will be little reason left to buy this game... but still. It's on sale all the time. Enjoy a little piece of history."

reviewText:
TL;DR at the bottom

Wow. Coming from a guy who spent a lot of time playing Left 4 Dead 2, I can personally say this game is actually really awesome. Some people simply don't play this game, because everything that's in this game is in Left 4 Dead 2. Which is true to a degree, however there are some differences. First of all, there are only Left 4 Dead campaigns (which is obviously expected). Second of all, There are no melee weapons either. Third of all, the community is almost dead.

Ok so why the hell would I recommend this game? Well, it feels like a better game. Let me explain. Valve wanted to create an amazing 4 player co-op zombie survival game and they did! It was pretty damn scary, it had great characters, the tone of the game was really dark, and it was a ton of fun! On top of that you could actually see your own legs! Left 4 Dead 2 just feels like an upgrade of the game by adding new campaigns, characters, and melee weapons. Left 4 Dead never got the attention it deserved (in my opinion) because Valve decided to release L4D2 way earlier than it was supposed to be released.

hat I'm trying to say is, Left 4 Dead feels more like a classic Valve game and feels like a simple game compared to Left 4 Dead 2. Left 4 Dead 2 is a great game, but Left 4 Dead is simply a classic.

TL;DR
Left 4 Dead is a great FPS game created by Valve that's taken place in the Zombie apocalypse. It's an amazing 4 player co-op game that anyone can enjoy! If you're still not satisfied of what this game has to offer, go buy L4D2.

Overall rating 9/10

reviewText:
If you're familiar with Left 4 Dead 2, this is basically the same game but streamlined. For the uninitiated, Left 4 Dead is a multiplayer FPS where four survivors must work together to survive a zombie apocalypse, fighting hordes of fast-moving Common infected and Special infected with unique abilities.

In this original iteration, only the Hunter (fast pouncer), Smoker (long-range snarer), Boomer (kamikaze horde summoner), Witch (extremely dangerous if alerted) and Tank (it is what it sounds like) appear.

There are four modes in L4D: Campaign (play through one of a number of 'campaigns' in the story), Versus (like Campaign but additional people can control the Special infected), Survival (the hardest mode, where you must hold out for as long as possible against the Infected and set time records), and singleplayer (Campaign with bots on your computer).

The gameplay is directed by an AI system named The Director, who spawns items & enemies, and changes the level depending on the status of the survivors. The harder the difficulty, the more contempt it has for you.

The presentation, as befitting most Valve games, is stellar. The campaigns are presented as movies, with 'credits' after the end displaying gameplay stats and a separate music Director controlling the incidental music. It does a good job of creating a zombie-film like atmosphere.

Only thing of concern is the community. It's not abysmal, but it's relatively small and you'll run into some toxic players, given how cooperative and intense this game can be. If you want to play Expert at all, be prepared to do some janky metagame stuff to fit in - killing players who are below 50 health when they reach the safehouse so they respawn at 50 being one example.


Now you might be wondering: with all of the official L4D campaigns ported over to the sequel, why should I play this? Well, there are a number of differences that for make L4D unique and worth playing for me and others even today, and even if it lacks Workshop mod support.


Regarding weaponry and equipment:

* The weapon animations are simply better than the sequel's. Fortunately, there are mods that port some of them to L4D2. There is also an HD port mod for the pump shotgun.

* The pistols are M1911s, which I much prefer over the L4D2 pistols. There is also also an HD port mod for them.

* There are less guns, which means more meaningful weaponry choices. Tier one only has the pump shotgun and Uzi; tier two has the auto shotgun, M16 and hunting rifle. The shotguns function the most different: if you reload them from an empty magazine you must rack the chamber before firing. This makes a difference on the harder difficulties.

* The melee in non-versus games does not suffer from fatigue; you can keep doing it as long as you need. This is helpful when there are no melee weapons to choose from!

* There are only pipe bombs and Molotov cocktails; and no adrenaline shots, defibrillators or ammo packs. Which, again, can make for more of a challenge.


Regarding your enemies:

* Less Special infected (no Jockey, Charger or Spitter) make for a different and some say harder experience, not in the least because the SI that remain are more dangerous here.

* The Common infected appear different and more true to what Valve had in mind.


Regarding performance:

* The game runs better than L4D2.

* The HUD is streamlined and looks better.


Regarding aesthetics and other stuff like that:

* There are different achievements in L4D; for example you do not get achievements in L4D2 for beating the original campaigns on Expert. If you want credit for doing so, you'll want to do it here.

* The little touch to the bot AI's weapon selection is missing in the L4D2 ports. In L4D2, Zoey uses assault rifles as well as hunting rifles, Louis uses shotguns, and Francis uses snipers. This is in contrast to their behaviour in L4D, where Louis would use the Uzi/M16, Francis uses shotguns, and Zoey would usually pick up the hunting rifle.

* L4D2's campaigns and aesthetics are action-horror oriented. L4D's are more horror-oriented. While this is largely carried over in the L4D2 ports of the original campaigns, the optimal experience is playing them in L4D.

* For those who enjoy glitches, there are a number in the original campaigns that have not been fixed. The Jesus Rock in Death Toll's finale is a prime example.

* You can see your legs when you look down.


Basically, Left 4 Dead distills the formula to its essence and consequently makes this first entry into the series a classic. I suppose this right here is why it's still being played in a nutshell.


Not to say that Left 4 Dead 2 isn't bad, because apart from the weapon animations and its larger but more toxic community it's really not worse - just different. If you want a different Left 4 Dead experience, or you want to ease your way into the franchise by picking it up at the source, I'd recommend this.

reviewText: This game is definitely one of my top favorite games, I've been playing this game ever since it has come out and it never gets old in my opinion, because of all the stuff to do. sure you can play single player or play campaign with others online, but also you can do versus, where you are the special infected trying to kill other online survivors, or vice versa. Another great thing about left 4 dead if the originality and unique types of zombies there are, this is not just your typical zombie game, you will be watching out everywhere for dreaded hunters, who jump very far just to tackle you and rip at you with their sharp fingers, Smokers, Who will constrict you with their tongue and hold you as you get hit by other zombies or as it claws at you. and boomers, who puke bile, attracting the common infected horde to attack you while you can barely see anything. And don't forget the witch, the scary thing is that your first time playing it, you would probably not have guessed she'd do what she did. Then there is the tank, who was once a roid head who is now probably the most feared thing in the game. Point is this is and always will be a classic zombie shooter game and has many thing to do and many ways to do them, and is definitely worth the buy.

reviewText:
I'm only recommending this if you have played L4D2 already, if you haven't played/bought that, please buy L4D2 rather than L4D1 since they cost the same amount anyway.

Anyway, ever since when the campaigns from L4D1 got ported to L4D2, this game got more and more less played. For a reason, it's more enjoyable though to play a single game as a party with campaigns from two games, rather than always switch between 2 games if you want to play different campaigns.
Campaigns itself and the whole scenario in L4D1 are better though, probably they aren't really that much different from what they are in L4D2 though to some people, so in case if you don't already see any difference between them yourself, you should just stick to the sequel.
The versus game on this one has more idea than in L4D2, since on L4D2 you just run to the safe room and that's it, with this you all have to maintain your health as good too rather than crawl to the safe room as a group.
Still, with that there's the one problem you would notice if you have played both games, there's half of the special infected that you can use in versus since there are more added zombies in the sequel. It's kind of like a preference if you don't like Chargers, Jockeys or Spitters, but I would find 2 Hunters, Smokers or Boomers a bit unfair altogether.

There are some things that you might miss from L4D2, like special weapons or throwables, or even some of the gamemodes. Making mostly only the Campaigns the core of this game, which it mostly is though of course. I don't think you would be able to get more than 4 people to get to play this in these days anyway now.

This is still a great game though, but I don't see any reason to spend money on this for the story, since as said, all the same campaigns are already in L4D2. There's even more story between The Sacrifice and The Passing than almost at any other part of the game and those both campaigns were added to L4D2 in the first place too.

Only thing that this has what L4D2 doesn't, is a one survival map. So if you're dying to get that, feel free to spend 20â‚¬ to get that rather than to search a custom map file for it somewhere for L4D2.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game to fans of co-op games. Even though Left 4 Dead 2 is technically better, the original still manages to be a pretty awesome game in it's own terms.

The game is split up into a bunch of campaigns, each split into five chapters/levels (excluding two campaigns). The first four levels require a team of characters to progress to a safe house. Along the way, you encounter or are attacked/ambushed by hundreds of zombies, and while they are pretty to defeat, the sheer number of attacking enemies can be overwhelming. Teamwork is a key element when playing on normal difficulty or over. Adding to the enemies are a number of minibosses, which require different strategies to defeat. Some are pretty easy, while others keep you on your toes. The fifth and final level/chapter in the campaign is normally some kind of extraction from the area, which requires players to defend themsevles in a certain area for a set amount of time. It can get pretty intense.

There are four characters to choose from before the start of the campaigns. There's a computer guy, a biker, a war veteran, and a college girl. There's not much of a difference with who you choose, it's more of a personal preferance. But even so, there's quite a bit of dialouge for each character, some for scripted events in the campaigns, and a ton of comments/quotes for player use during gameplay. This is useful for players who don't have a microphone during multiplayer.

Speaking of multiplayer, there's an interesting versus mode, where some players play as the survivors, while the others take control of the game's minibosses. And not to mention a survival mode.

The graphics are pretty good. Even though this game is from 2009, it still holds up in today's standards. Lighting and flashlight mechanics are impressive. Textures are mostly high quality. Depending on your rig, the game maintains a good-maximum framerate, even when you have thirty zombies running around in your field of vision. I was surprised that the game ran so well, since I have a pretty bad graphics card for gaming. I managed to put almost all settings to max. On the negative side, I see black spots like a radius around fire ingame, although I'm sure it's just my graphics card (Intel 3000 integrated).

All in all, I think this a great game. I myself play mainly solo, but this is certainly best played coopertatively. Worth the money. 9/10.

Worth every cent.

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead is the game that started this recent wave of coop games and it's by far one of the best ones available despite it's many problems.

The basic game mode, campaign, pits you and three of your friends against the undead hordes in an attempt to flee to safety. You play through a series of maps fighting common infected as well as various special infected that provide a greater challenge. As you go through the maps, from saferoom to saferoom you pick up consumable items and get better and better weapons. Although the lower difficulties are so easy a child could complete them the higher ones provide a great level of challenge and are nearly unachievable without a team of good players.

In the second game mode, versus, you play a four vs. four matchup where teams take turns at playing survivors as well as infected. As the infected team you spawn as one of the various special infected and try to inflict as much damage as possible before the survivors reach the saferoom.

While campaign is mostly a smooth play, provided you have friends to play with, versus has a number of problems that make it hard to enjoy in the long one. Chiefly is that the game was never balanced in any meaningful way so the survivors can quite easily complete every map taking a minimum of damage. Without imposing some sort of house rules on what the survivors are allowed to do any organized versus game quickly becomes a rather boring affair.

Another rather large problem is the number of bugs still in the game, despite Valve doing almost weekly patches for several years the tank, the infected's only real game changer, will still occasionally spawn outside the map and instantly die or spawn on top of a burning barrel which works much the same.

Although underneath the horrific balance and game ending bugs is a rather solid game it is also a game that requires organized team play. You can't simply jump on a random server without expecting to get disappointed. I was lucky enough to have a number of great friends to play with yet whenever I booted the game up by myself I always found it to be a frustrating and bland affair trying to get any sense of game going with randoms. It's a game that can only really be enjoyed in gathers.

Graphically the game is quite good despite being on the now aging Source engine. Various poor design decisions mark the experience though, most notably the unusually low skyboxes on certain maps.

The sound is fairly functional, each breed of infected carrying with it a number of distinct sounds that'll always keep you on your toes.

Left 4 Dead is a good game but it does have some problems, the most important of which is that it isn't a game you can just buy for yourself, you have to have friends to play with and while I enjoy playing coop with people I know not having to option to occasionally jump on and play a quick session without planning it beforehand really hurts the game in the long run.

Also, any review of Left 4 Dead would be incomplete without a mention of Left 4 Dead 2 because that's what killed this game. These days you'll only find a few games going at any given time and for a Valve game to have such a short lifespan is just atrocious.

reviewText:
To put it in one sentence, L4D is a challenging FPS with great replayability and one of the best co-ops there are.

Pros:
-Clean graphics, smooth gameplay experience
-Challenging AI
-Co-op which really feels like co-op - acting as a team is crucial for completing the campaigns
-Good replayability, each session is different even on the same map
-Although there are only five kinds of enemies, they are dressed according to the environment, thus complementing the gameplay
-Available add-on maps from the community

Cons:
-It's possible only to equip two weapons at the same time (option 1: a pistol/two pistols with infinite ammo; option 2: sniper rifle, assault rifle, shotgun, military shotgun or machine pistol with limited ammo)
-Too often there are situations when zombies catch you by surprise (especially, smokers and hunters) - but's maybe it's just me being a noob
-In order to have a better aim, you need to crouch and that's inconvenient
-Friendly fire is a mandatory option

My overall rating: 8/10

reviewText:
Left 4 Dead is a first-person, cooperative shooter that takes place in a zombie apocalyptic Pennsylvania where you play as Bill, Francis, Louis, or Zoey and fight the hordes until you reach rescue. The game sounds very obvious and doesn't sound too special nowadays. However, does the game still appeal to gamers in today's standards?

Before I continue on to this review, I got Left 4 Dead in mid-June 2009. What is that previous sentence relevant or important? Well, let me tell you. If you had brought Left 4 Dead from November 2008 to December 2010, Left 4 Dead was a magnificant game. Heck, it was a great classic and a perfect gem. When Left 4 Dead was released back on November 2008, the game spawn a whole new genre: Multiplayer Cooperative. Sure, there were some games that had that genre, but Left 4 Dead won over the general gamer's perception of a true, cooperative game that you have to rely on your friends to help and assist you. Arguably, Left 4 Dead had also build a foundation of a new video game genre (which is now getting a bit overboard now): Zombie games.

Left 4 Dead is a multiplayer game that put you and your three other friends (or players) in various campaigns (which takes around 45 minutes or so, depending on difficulty level or pace) to reach rescue (or finale that is called).  What is interesting for Left 4 Dead is that you replay the campaigns over and over, but each replay feels different" or new in some extent. This best feature is known as AI Director. AI Director is a system where items
recommended: and various props are randomized in different locations
hoursPlayed: making the players not always assuming that the items are in that one
helpfulPercent: this increase replay value by a good margin. Left 4 Dead's atmosphere is actually very immersive and impressive for an aged game. In addition
votesHelpful:
Left 4 Dead's Survival Mode is worth playing and is very fun so it is encouraged for the potental buyer to try it out.

A summary of positive features...

+ Strong
votesTotal: cooperative multiplayer without a doubt\n+ It is really fun playing with your friends
votesFunny:
and a lot better when you make new friends on the game
+ AI Director increase its replay value
+ Very immersive and night atmosphere which is better than Left 4 Dead 2 (even when Left 4 Dead's maps are transferred over to the second game)
+ Survival Mode is really fun and really worth playing to get your personal best
commentsCount: breaking records
column17:
you might make new friends when you play Survival Mode

A summary of negative aspects about the game...

- Versus Mode is an interesting concept and can be fun
column18: but it is ruined by arrogant players\n- The game used to have over 30
column19: 000+ players when I played back in 2009 and 2010. Nowadays
column20:
it is around 500 players thanks to Left 4 Dead 2 and Valve's abandonment when the sequel was released.
- The game has aged and less than 500 players are around. Might be a bit discouraged for a potential buyer to get it

Left 4 Dead was a legendary classic that spawn two gameplay features that remains popular today and it is highly recommended."
